creditline: Gift of Kiran Kapoor in loving memory of my father, Vineet Kapoor, and my grandmother, Urmil Kapoor
description: group of 17 ornaments received glued on red velvet mount and framed in gilt and light wood finish frame (not glazed): .1: animal head with leaves at top, extending up to a point (2-3/4" tall) .2: square with round organic element at center and circles in corners; fragments of pink pigments (1-7/16" tall) .3: square with spiraling stem and leaf; dark colored (1-1/4" tall) .4: square with round central element with trident and leaves; circles in corners; traces of pink pigment (1-1/4" tall) .5: bird's head with pronounced teeth and pointed headdress (3-1/16" tall) .6: trapezoid form with floral motif (1-5/8" tall) .7: rectangular with round elements forming a circle with a wave-like leaf at center; tick marks along edges (1-7/16" tall) .8: eye-shape with vertical skirted element at center inside a circle (2-5/8" tall) .9: diamond shaped with round element opening at center, with jagged edges on lid (1-7/8" tall) .10: openwork partial square (one side lost); floral design; traces of pink pigment (1-3/4" tall) .11: diamond shape with incised organic leaf motifs (2-1/4" tall) .12: eye-shaped with central floral design, surrounded by circles (1-7/8" tall) .13: square with four-lobed symmetrical floral design (1-7/16" tall) .14: eye-shaped; funeral pyre with horizontal human figure with flames below and two animals walking over body (2-1/16" tall) .15: diamond shaped with pot with flames (?) and curving elements (1-1/4" tall) .16: diamond shaped with diamond floral form (1-13/16" tall) .17: bird's head with teeth and pointed headdress; slightly asymmetrical (2-7/8" tall)
text: This assortment of  bone ornaments would have served as plaques within an elaborate Ritual Apron (Rugya), with the diamond-shaped plaques--delicately carved with auspicious symbols, and abstracted floral motifs—which would have joined together a network of double-stranded beads, held by a belt, with the oblong-plaques, carved with  kirttimukha (face of glory) motifs, suspended at the bottom. They would have been part of an elaborate ‘dancing’ ensemble of bone ornaments, including crowns, armlets, anklets, and neck ornaments worn by elite practitioners of Vajrayana  (or Tantric) Buddhism in Tibet at important ceremonies, to ward of evil spirits while serving as a reminder of the transience of life.
title: Group of 17 Tibetan bone apron ornaments
